What is Maven?

Maven is a package manager and a build tool for Java.

  • Open source project managed by the Apache Software Foundation

  • Project website: https://maven.apache.org/

  • First release in 2004

    • Over 15 years old
    • A very stable tool

  • One of the most popular build tools for Java, as reported in:

    • Snyk's JVM Ecosystem Report 2021
    • JRebel's 2020 Java Technology Report
    • IntelliJ's State of Developer Ecosystem 2019

Maven's objective:

To allow a developer to comprehend the complete state of a development effort in the shortest period of time

Read more at https://maven.apache.org/what-is-maven.html

How?

  • Making the build process easy:

    • Maven will shield you from many details
    • But it doesnâ€™t eliminate the need to know about the underlying mechanisms

  • Providing a uniform build system:

    • Maven builds a project using its project object model (POM) and a set of plugins
    • If you understand how one Maven project works, you know how all of them work

  • Providing quality project information, such as:

    • Change log created directly from source control
    • Dependencies used by the project
    • Unit test reports including coverage

  • Encouraging better development practices:

    • Standard directory layout
    • Good testing practices:
      • Separate test source code
      • Naming conventions to locate and execute tests
      • Test cases setup their environment

What is a package manager?

  • A package manager is a tool that automates the process of installing, upgrading, configuring, and removing software programs and libraries from a computer system in a consistent manner

  • System-level package managers:

    • macOs: Homebrew and MacPorts
    • Linux: Advanced Package Tool (APT) and Yum

  • Application-level package managers:

    • Java: Maven and Gradle
    • Javascript/TypeScript: npm and Yarn
    • Python: pip
    • Ruby: RubyGems

  • You can find a list of package managers at

    https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_software_package_management_systems

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Package_manager

Why use a package manager?

  • We want to reuse other people's code and we want to share our work with others.

  • We can avoid checking large binaries files into our git repository.

  • As projects get more complex, we need help to handle complex dependencies trees.

  • Package managers tend to centralize hosting and distribution of packages. They make it easier for us to find and get the packages we need.

  • Package managers establish a shared convention for managing libraries. They make it easier for us to understand which packages (and their specific versions) a project use.

  • We want to compartmentalize the installation of dependencies.

https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/questions/372444/why-prefer-a-package-manager-over-a-library-folder

What is a build tool?

  • A build tool is a program that automates the creation of executable applications from source code

  • Build automation is the act of scripting tasks that developers do in their day-to-day activities, like:

    • Downloading dependencies
    • Compiling source code into binary code
    • Running tests
    • Packaging that binary code
    • Deploying to production systems

  • Examples of build tools:

    • Java: Ant, Maven, and Gradle
    • Javascript: gulp and Grunt
    • .NET: MSBuild
    • Multi-language: Bazel

  • You can find a list of build automation tools at

    https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_build_automation_software

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/7249871/what-is-a-build-tool

Why use a build tool?

  • In a small project, you may not need one, as you can simply invoke the build process manually.

  • When projects get larger, this stops being practical. It starts to get very hard keeping track of what needs to be built, in what sequence and what dependencies there are in the building process.

  • A build automation tool allows the build process to be quicker and more consistent!

  • It is also lot easier to document how to build a project:

    mvn clean package

  • Everyone can user their own IDE

  • Modern software development practice adopts continuous integration workflows, which require build automation.

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/7249871/what-is-a-build-tool

Maven advantages

  • Quick project setup

    • Convention over configurations

  • Modular projects

  • Mature dependency management

  • Mature project build lifecycle

  • Robust plugin community

  • Very good IDE support, including IntelliJ IDEA, Eclipse, and VS Code

Somethings people do not like in Maven

  • The use of XML to describe projects

    • XML is generally disliked by younger developers
    • The project description file gets very big, very fast

  • Maven is harder to extend than Gradle

  • Maven is slower than Gradle

Maven, a de facto standard

  • Maven established "standards" that are used by other build tools:

    • Maven standard directory layout
    • Artifact naming
    • Artifact repository

Our goal

  • Our main goal is for you to learn the basic concepts related to package managers and build tools.

  • A considerable part of this knowledge is transferable to other tools that you may use in the future, such as Gradle, npm, and Grunt.

  • Understanding Java's build process is valuable for those venturing into the DevOps world.

  • We do not expect you to be a Maven guru.

  • You will have to use Maven in your course project.
